section: The Joint Venturers agree and declare that this association for the carrying on of a joint venture business operation does not, and is not intended to create a partnership, for either legal or United States income tax purposes, each Party recognizing that the other is willing and able to contribute capital, labor, and services for the operation of a successful joint venture business. Further, each Party elects under the authority of Section 761(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (the "Code"), as amended and all successor statutes, to be excluded from the application of all of the provisions of Subchapter K of Chapter 1 of the Subtitle A of the Code, and the Parties agree that the election out of Subchapter K of Chapter 1 of Subtitle A of the Code shall, if necessary, be manifested by their execution and filing of all appropriate documentation.
explanation: While the agreement explicitly states the intention to be treated as a joint venture and not a partnership for tax purposes and elects out of Subchapter K, the operational structure and distribution terms (specifically the guaranteed payment to PVSS in Section 9) may be construed by the IRS as a partnership. Guaranteed payments are a characteristic of partnerships, potentially contradicting the stated intent to avoid partnership classification. The IRS assesses the substance of the relationship over the form; therefore, this section creates a legal risk. If the IRS determines the arrangement is in fact a partnership, the parties would be subject to partnership tax rules, which could have significant financial and legal ramifications that are contrary to what is written in this agreement.

section: Distributions may only be made if after any distribution is made, the Joint Venture assets are in excess of all liabilities of the Joint Venture. Each distribution shall be made ratably to the Joint Venturers according to their prorata interest in the Joint Venture as shown in Section 6. Notwithstanding the foregoing, PVSS shall be entitled to receive a guaranteed payment of $10,000 per month, regardless of the Joint Venture's profitability.
explanation: The provision stating that distributions can only be made if assets exceed liabilities is directly contradicted by the guaranteed payment of $10,000 per month to PVSS, irrespective of profitability. If the Joint Venture has insufficient assets to cover its liabilities, the guaranteed payment to PVSS would violate the previous sentence. This creates an in-text contradiction and introduces ambiguity and potential legal issues regarding distribution priorities and obligations.

section: However, in the event of a dispute regarding the valuation of assets during liquidation, Collectible Concepts Group, Inc. will have the final say on the asset's value.
explanation: This clause gives Collectible Concepts Group, Inc. (CCGI) unilateral control over asset valuation during liquidation. This could potentially lead to an unfair distribution of assets if CCGI undervalues them, especially since income and loss are divided 50/50 (Section 6). This clause can be viewed as structurally unfair because it allows one party to unilaterally affect the financial outcome of the liquidation process, potentially disadvantaging the other party and contradicting the implied principle of equitable distribution.
